webTitle: Mathias Cormann hits pause on future of financial advice reforms

fields.standfirst: 'I want to have further conversations with key stakeholders and remind them what they agreed to,' finance minister says
fields.body:
The finance minister has “paused” plans to immediately implement controversial changes to financial advice regulation as he seeks to calm the growing opposition from financial planning, seniors and consumers groups to the changes.

Mathias Cormann, who regained responsibility for the so-called “future of financial advice (Fofa)” reforms after the assistant treasurer, Arthur Sinodinos, stood aside because of developments at the Independent Commission against Corruption, told Guardian Australia he had shelved plans to table regulations imposing the changes this week.

“I am not going to jump the gun,” he said. “I want to have further conversations with key stakeholders and remind them what they agreed to before the election. I have pressed pause on the regulations – I will press the button again once I am satisfied most people are back on the same page.”

The financial planning industry was behind the changes Cormann, as the responsible shadow minister, took to the 2013 election, but in recent weeks the Financial Planning Association has said the government’s proposal to reintroduce commissions for “general advice” in some cases is a “retrograde step”.

The group’s concerns added to a growing chorus from such groups as National Seniors, Council on the Ageing, Choice and Industry Super Australia.

The chief executive of Industry Super Australia, David Whiteley, said Cormann's announcement was "a timely circuit breaker and a victory for common sense".

“Minister Cormann should be congratulated for this intervention. A return to consensus and industry agreement is exactly what the public and the industry needs,” he said.

Cormann remains committed to the government’s proposed changes but appears to recognise the scope of the growing political backlash. He said he would not be changing the policy the Coalition took to the election but “if we are having conversations it is always possible we could tweak things”.

Legislation to impose the changes was introduced into the House of Representatives alongside the government’s “bonfire of the regulations”. But with that legislation unlikely to pass the current Senate, and with many aspects of the former Labor government’s financial advice laws due to come into effect on 1 July, the government had planned to table regulations at the end of this week to impose immediate change. It is the final sitting week before the May budget.

The government’s laws have been referred to the Senate economics committee, which will report on 16 June. Even if the laws do not pass the upper house, waiting for that report would still leave the government two sitting weeks to table regulations to force through its changes before Labor’s existing laws come into effect on 1 July.

Cormann insists that allowing payments to people such as bank tellers for providing “general advice” does not amount to a reintroduction of commissions and is need to “level the playing field” between banks and the industry superannuation funds.

He says a lot of the concerns being raised are based on “misunderstandings and misinformation”. And he is clearly frustrated by the political storm brewing over a policy for which he had achieved widespread support before the September poll.

But some organisations say their views have hardened because they now understand the real impact of the Coalition’s changes. “We’ve become far more concerned since we saw the detail and since we have taken independent legal advice,” said Michael O’Neill, chief executive of National Seniors Australia.

“It seemed all very well when it was general principles before the election, but now we are worried and so are a lot of our members.”

He said he had met Sinodinos. “He didn’t see our concerns as significant,” said O’Neill, who is due to meet Cormann next week.

Matthew Rowe, the head of the Financial Planning Association, has said: “We don’t believe that a commission should be payable on any form of investment or superannuation, regardless of whether it’s specific personal advice or general advice.”

The former government’s laws followed the high-profile collapses of financial advice companies such as Storm Financial and Opes Prime, but Cormann argues they go further than the bipartisan report into the causes of those collapses.

As Guardian Australia reported last week, victims who together lost billions in the collapse of those financial advice firms are joining the campaign against the government’s planned changes to financial advice regulation.

The shadow treasurer, Chris Bowen, said the government should now drop the Fofa changes, rather than just press pause on them.

“This is a big blow to the credibility of the government and Arthur Sinodinos in particular … This has been a botched process … These changes have the potential to do real damage to Australian consumers and investors,” he said. “We think they should just admit they’ve got it terribly, terribly wrong.”

He called on Cormann to conduct his consultations transparently.

Bowen cited Tony Abbott’s recent comments that it was a “given” that financial advisers would always act in the best interests of their clients, and said the prime minister seemed to have forgotten collapses such as Storm Financial.

webTitle: Why are people's views of inflation at odds with the economic reality? | Greg Jericho

fields.standfirst: Australia's inflation rate and cost of living are both at record lows, just don't expect anyone to believe the official figures
fields.body:
If you were to believe politicians and sections of the media, the cost of living is rising faster than ever. That many people believe this to be true is evident from both Kevin Rudd and Tony Abbott making the issue a major part of their election campaigns last year despite inflation being at near record lows.

The Reserve Bank last week released a paper which compared the consumer price index with cost of living, and also examined why people’s view of cost of living and inflation is at odds with the reality.

One of the major reasons for the disparity is people give greater weight to large irregular expenses than does the Bureau of Statistics when it calculates inflation.

The ABS uses around 100,000 different prices for around 120 groups of goods and services each quarter to calculate inflation. The items and groups are fixed and weighted for household’s annual expenditure. Thus electricity prices account for 1.99%, water and sewerage for 0.9%, and secondary education for 1.26%. But each of these items comes in either a quarterly or annual bill, and their price rise occurs only annually, as do property rates and charges (which account for 1.26% of the CPI):

So you “feel” these big price rises more than you do the small rises or even falling prices of incidental purchases you make which might actually account for more of your annual spending.

Political parties and media know this, which is why they focus on these expenses when discussing or reporting inflation.

But the RBA noted that even among regular purchases research suggests people notice the rises more than the falls. Essentially we don’t balance out a price increase in one item with a price fall in another.

Finally, a major problem is when we measure our own cost of living we are really measuring cost of lifestyle. We are now spending more in total than we used to because our standard of living is growing. Thus we’re not comparing the cost of achieving the same standard of living, but rather the cost of a reasonable standard of living – and what is “reasonable” is getting more expensive.

This means the “perceived increases in the cost of living may partly reflect the cost of attaining a higher standard of living for many households”. That is, our cost of living is increasing because we choose to spend more on better quality (or better "branded") items. Trying to keep up with the Joneses however is not inflation.

Interestingly, our own actions can actually make the CPI higher than our “personal inflation rate”. Firstly, unlike the ABS which must use a fixed bundle of goods and service, we can substitute our purchases. For example in 2011 after Cyclone Yasi the price of bananas soared to $15kg. But did this mean everyone was suddenly paying around 400% more for bananas? Not really. Most people just stopped buying bananas for a few months and bought something else.

The RBA estimates this “substitution bias” adds around 0.25 to 0.5 percentage points to the annual CPI over what the average household experiences.

Similarly we are able to buy what may be the same item but at a better quality than we did before. If the price increases in line with quality, then the cost of living is actually unchanged, but if quality goes up and the price remains flat, the cost of living has actually declined.

While the ABS does regularly update the quality of items such as computers and IT (so they’re not still calculating the price of a Pentium or Windows 95), it is tougher to measure quality for things like education or health. If quality and price both go up but the ABS doesn’t realise it, it effectively means the CPI is actually measuring a quality improvement rather than a price increase. The RBA suggests this can add up to 0.5 percentage points as well.

But aside from these difficulties with measuring inflation, the big problem is that the CPI is an average of everyone’s inflation. It doesn’t care about your income, whether you rent or own a house. All it cares about is where you live.

The ABS does produce cost of living indices which consider the cost of living according to your source of income – wage, pension, or government benefits. These measures also consider the cost of mortgages payments, which the CPI does not.

But the RBA notes that inflation also varies according to whether you own a house or rent and also your household income. This accords with data from the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling (NATSEM).

The NATSEM cost of living indices, consistent with the RBA’s research, show that cost of living for those on lower incomes has risen significantly higher than the wealthiest since the GFC:

A major reason is those on lower incomes are more likely to be renting, and for home owners the interest rates cuts since the GFC have greatly dampened the cost of living.

That many people believe this to be true is evident from both Kevin Rudd and Tony Abbott making the issue a major part of their election campaigns last year despite inflation being at near record lows. The ABS uses around 100,000 different prices for around 120 groups of goods and services each quarter to calculate inflation. The items and groups are fixed and weighted for household’s annual expenditure. Thus electricity prices account for 1.99%, water and sewerage for 0.9%, and secondary education for 1.26%. But each of these items comes in either a quarterly or annual bill, and their price rise occurs only annually, as do property rates and charges (which account for 1.26% of the CPI): So you “feel” these big price rises more than you do the small rises or even falling prices of incidental purchases you make which might actually account for more of your annual spending. Political parties and media know this, which is why they focus on these expenses when discussing or reporting inflation. But the RBA noted that even among regular purchases research suggests people notice the rises more than the falls. Essentially we don’t balance out a price increase in one item with a price fall in another. We are now spending more in total than we used to because our standard of living is growing. Thus we’re not comparing the cost of achieving the same standard of living, but rather the cost of a reasonable standard of living – and what is “reasonable” is getting more expensive. This means the “perceived increases in the cost of living may partly reflect the cost of attaining a higher standard of living for many households”. webTitle: Egg cartons going plastic as Tesco finds a cracking solution to leaky cardboard

fields.standfirst: More than 1 million eggs a year will be saved as pulp or cardboard cartons are replaced by recyclable plastic
fields.body:
Egg cartons made of pulp or cardboard are to be replaced by recyclable plastic packaging to save more than a million free-range eggs from going to waste every year after a successful trial by Britain's biggest egg retailer.

Tesco's free-range eggs are currently sold in pulp cartons so if an egg breaks in transit, it can seep through the box and damage packs beneath.

But the supermarket has trialled a recyclable plastic packaging made from old drinks bottles. When an egg breaks, the seepage can be contained in one pack.

Over the past eight weeks, Tesco has trialled the new 12-egg packaging in nearly 200 stores served by depots in the Livingston area of Scotland and Belfast area of Northern Ireland.

Tesco is the UK's largest egg retailer, selling around 1.3 billion eggs every year.

Tesco spokesman Lee Gray said: "We know that plastic packs reduce food waste – now we have a pack that will reduce food waste and offer customers a more environmentally friendly packaging solution.

"If used across all our free-range egg range then it will save on average more than one million eggs each year. The results of the trial are very positive and we hope to be able to roll out the packaging by the end of the year."

webTitle: Energy watchdog Ofgem fails to challenge big six suppliers' dominance

fields.standfirst: New market-share figures prompt calls for action to fix "broken" energy market, as domestic power bills continue to soar
fields.body:
Ofgem, the energy watchdog, has failed to make inroads into the market dominance of the big six suppliers over the last five years – an omission that many believe is responsible for soaring domestic power bills – figures published today show.

The numbers from the Department of Energy and Climate Change (Decc) come alongside an appeal from the consumer champion Which? and the Federation of Small Businesses for a full competition inquiry into what they describe as a "broken" energy market.

A preliminary review by Ofgem and other City regulators into the dominance of firms such as SSE, E.ON and British Gas is expected to be published on Thursday and recommend a deeper probe by the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA). Caroline Flint, the shadow energy and climate change secretary, warned that such a probe would have the confidence of consumers only if it came up with robust action to rebalance the market in their favour.

The Decc numbers, provided to and published by Flint after a written question in parliament earlier this year, show a market that is next to static. SSE, E.ON and RWE npower hold exactly the same market share in gas now as over five years ago, 15%, 13% and 12% respectively. British Gas, by far the largest of the big six suppliers, held 44% of the gas market in December 2007 and still held 40% by December 2012, while EDF saw its share rise from 7% to 9%.

The electricity picture is similar, with British Gas increasing its share of the market from 22% to 25% over the five-year period, while E.ON dropped 1% and EDF and Scottish Power held their shares steady at 13% and 12%.

In both gas and electricity markets, the big six control 99% of the business, although that figure should have dropped since as the November price rises highlighted the benefits of moving to smaller independent companies.

First Utility, Ovo, Ecotricity and other new suppliers have repeatedly argued their ability to grow their market share is being thwarted by the dominance of the big six and the anti-competitive nature of the market.

Flint, who has promised a radical shake-up if Labour return to power in 2015, said consumers needed to be given new confidence that the prices they pay are fair. "Anything that can help shine a light on the workings of the energy market is welcome. But consumers will be rightly disappointed if the government uses this review as an excuse to kick the problem of rip-off energy bills into the long grass. We have hardly been short of reviews of the energy market in recent years – but what has been missing is decisive action to protect consumers.

"Our plans will break up the big energy companies, put an end to their secret deals and make tariffs simpler and fairer. And until these reforms kick in, we will put a stop to unfair price rises by freezing energy bills until 2017, saving the average household £120."

Richard Lloyd, executive director of Which?, and Mike Cherry, national policy chairman at the Federation of Small Businesses, urged Ofgem, the CMA and the Office of Fair Trading to refer the energy market for further assessment, claiming that nine out of 10 consumers would support this.

In joint letters to the three watchdogs to be sent out on Monday, they say: "Top of our concerns is the need to increase competition and make trading transparent. For too long the lack of competition in the energy market has not been addressed. It is now time for radical changes that deliver an effective, competitive market that delivers for everyone, before the scale of this crisis grows."
